Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Rise of Iron in the Land of the Golden Fleece: The Technology and Organization of Metal Production in Late Bronze Age and Early Iron Age Colchis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The modern perception that technological success and failure are exclusively the result to objective, quantifiable material properties has colored the way scholars have studied technological change in the past. The development of metallurgy has been particularly susceptible to these misperceptions, in part because metals remain a fundamental part of modern industry. A broader anthropological perspective is necessary to understand how social and cultural factors influence technological change.

The NSF-supported dissertation research, to be carried out by Nathaniel Erb-Satullo with the supervision on Professor Karl Lamberg-Karlovsky, will investigate a number of key questions about the technology and organization of metal production at the end of the Bronze Age and the beginning of the Iron Age (c. 1500-500 BC). In many areas of western Asia, the beginnings of widespread iron usage are correlated with substantial political and social change. Archaeologists have long sought to place this technological change into a broader framework of political and social changes. Some argue that the rise of iron technology was related to a breakdown in elite-controlled copper and tin trade networks, leading to the exploitation of geologically abundant iron ores. Others argue that the development related to a series of technological innovations which made iron a harder and more effective tool than bronze. Little research has focused on this transition from the perspective of the metal producers themselves.

The research program funded by this grant will examine the relationship between copper and iron production, with a focus on the primary contexts of production. The principal investigators hypothesize that that iron and bronze production were closely linked with one another, and that early iron producers drew extensively on knowledge gained from earlier technological traditions. Moreover, initial data suggests that, in contrast to other more intensively studied regions, bronze production was highly dispersed, with smelting, casting, smithing occurring at large numbers of small-scale sites. This mode of organization contrasts dramatically from more intensively studied regions of the Middle East, calling into question long-held notions about iron representing a "democratic" alternative to elite-controlled bronze.

Using a combination of survey, test excavations, and laboratory analysis of production debris, Erb-Satullo and his British and Georgian colleagues will test these hypotheses, examining technological decision-making in its social, economic, and political context. In addition to addressing key questions about the development of iron production in western Asia, the research will contribute to the growing body of research which shows that technological invention and adoption is deeply embedded within a society's social and cultural systems. Understanding these dimensions of technological change is essential in a world where rapid technology transfer offers both opportunities and pitfalls for solving many pressing social and environmental problems.

More directly, this research will foster increased collaboration between Georgian and Western scholars, and increase awareness of the Republic of Georgia. Despite its rich history, varied landscapes, and traditions of hospitality, Georgia remains a little known country in the West. Greater engagement between Georgia and the international community, through collaborative projects and responsible tourism, can assist Georgia in facing the many challenges of a newly independent country.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Archaeological studies of ancient technology provide a long-term perspective on the processes of innovation adoption and diffusion. Understanding the structural factors that stimulated or suppressed innovation in complex technological systems is important for understanding how present day societies approach innovation. This is not to argue that the process of innovation today is identical to the way it was thousands of years ago. Nevertheless, the study of innovation in past societies encourages us to reflect on how cultural and social factors impact our view of technology, an important lesson for the present day, when technology is ever more thoroughly embedded in the social fabric of our world.

            At its core, the dissertation research funded by this NSF DDIG grant addresses a fundamental question: what effect does a complex technological system—with all its accompanying social practices, beliefs, and ways of doing things—have on the development of new innovations? Do complex technologies spur further innovation, or are these systems so fixed in their approach to a problem that they are incapable of systemic change? Both lines of thinking can be seen in today’s discussions of technology. The first is exemplified by the sequential release of new, incrementally-improved versions of smart phones, tablet and computers, while the latter is discernible in “disruptive” technologies that spread precisely because they represent a systemic break from previous practices.

            My research focused on one such systemic change in the past—the development of iron technology. The systemic effects of iron technology were not immediate apparent. Ultimately, however, the wider geological availability of iron relative to copper and bronze opened up much larger supplies of metal, presaging the broad use of metal in modern society. I examined the effect of an expansive tradition of bronze production on the development of iron technology in the Caucasus mountains, focusing on eastern Black Sea Region of Colchis.

            The first task of the project was to understand the economic organization of the bronze production industry. I reconstructed the technology, chronology and spatial organization of a large landscape of smelting sites producing copper, the main constituent of bronze. Individual smelting sites were relatively small, usually consisting of one or two furnaces, and small heap of waste debris, mostly slag and furnace fragments. Chemical and microscopic analysis of the slag shows that metalworkers at these sites were using ore from geologically distinct deposits, meaning that there was little coordination of mining activity, even between contemporary sites that were spatially proximate. Despite the modest scale of individual workshops, however, the aggregate scale of production was massive. My colleagues and I mapped dozens of sites, providing a small window into what was undoubtedly an expansive production industry covering much of the region. This pattern of production contrasts dramatically with contemporary copper production landscapes elsewhere in the Middle East at the time. Moreover, the technology of production carried out at these sites was far from simple, requiring several intermediate stages to extract copper metal from sulfide ores. Metalworkers were able to maintain high temperatures and reducing conditions for long periods of time in relatively large reaction volumes, all important techniques that, while not strictly necessary for basic copper production, are requirements for the successful smelting of iron.

            The second phase of research involved the examination of extensive collections of metal objects in hoards and mortuary contexts, determining when and when iron artifacts came into use. I showed that the appearance of iron, while delayed relative to neighboring regions like Anatolia, proceeded quite rapidly. Early iron artifacts closely mimic the forms of those made of bronze, suggesting a close communication between craftspeople working both metals. The wide availability of copper, and traditions associated with its production, engendered technological conservatism initially. However, a series of social changes occurring in the early-1st millennium BC increased interest in public display of wealth, producing social conditions where competition between emerging elite lineages stimulated the production of new crafts and materials—iron being foremost among them. In these altered circumstances, the extensive pyrotechnological skills within the dispersed community of metalworkers facilitated the rapid expansion of local iron production, a development that would have been impossible without the pre-existing bronze industry.  

            In sum, this research shows that technological systems are not inherently innovative or conservative. Rather, the impact of a technological system on innovation is dependent on a broader set of social conditions. On a more immediate level, this analysis shows that iron’s emergence in the Black Sea coastal region of the South Caucasus differed from the more extensively studied regions to the South, illustrating the value of examining past technological change within its specific social context.
